questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by ________
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include:

Muscle  Nerve Supply

Trapezius

 Accessory nerve

Latissimus dorsi

 Thoracodorsal nerve

Levator scapulae

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Rhomboid major and minor

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Other options:

Option B: The suprascapular nerve innervates the supra- and infraspinatus muscles.

Option D: The subscapular nerves supply the teres major and subscapularis muscles.

questions.text: The image shows cardiac action potential graphs. At the point indicated by ‘A’,
questions.solution:
At the beginning of plateau phase, Slow Calcium channels open.

Phases of cardiac action potential

  • 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot
    • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+channels
  • 1→ Initial rapid repolarization
    • Due to closure of Na+channels and opening up of K+channels
  • 2→ Plateau phase
    • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+channels
  • 3→ Late rapid repolarization
  • 4→ Baseline (RMP)
    • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+efflux through K+ channels.
  • Until about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be seen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

Laboratory Tests

Pernicious Anemia (B12 Deficiency)

Folic Acid Deficiency

Serum B12 level

Decreased

Normal

Serum folic acid level

Normal

Decreased

Serum LDH level

Increased

Normal

Achlorhydria

Present

Absent

Schilling Test

Positive

Negative

Methyl malonyl CoA in urine

Present

Absent

Neurological signs

Present

Absent

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough with sputum and weight loss. He has a history of not completing treatment for tuberculosis thrice in the past. XDR-TB is suspected. How is XDR-TB defined?

choices.text: Resistant to INH + Amikacin + Ofloxacin + Ethambutol
Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin

questions.solution:
XDR-TB (Extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as MDR TB (Resistant to rifampicin  and isoniazid) + Resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) + resistance to one injectable second line drug (Amikacin or kanamycin or capreomycin). 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen -TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.


Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

Lfx: Levofloxacin

H: Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in a hypertensive patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors or ARBs can be considered as a treatment of choice in hypertensive patients with diabetes because of the renoprotective action. It benefits diabetic patients by reducing the risk of occurrence/progression of diabetic nephropathy.

They are recommended in patients with CKD irrespective of diabetes status as they can delay the progression of nephropathy.

Option A: Thiazide diuretics worsens glycemic control and are not preferred in diabetic patients.

Option B: Beta-blockers especially non-selective blockers worsen glycemic control.

Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on glycemic control and can be used in diabetes.

questions.text: Multi-dose activated charcoal acts by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Multidose activated charcoal is used for enhanced elimination of a toxin.

The techniques used for general management of poisoning can be classified into

  Examples
Gastrointestinal decontamination

Orogastric Lavage

Activated Charcoal

Whole Bowel Irrigation
Enhanced elimination

Multi-dose activated charcoal

Urinary alkalinization

Extracorporeal removal (Hemodialysis, Hemoperfusion)
Administration of antidote

Mechanical Antidotes

Chemical Antidotes

Physiological Antidotes

Pharmacological Antidotes

Multi-dose activated charcoal — In some instances, patients may benefit from the repeated administration of activated charcoal. MDAC facilitates the passage of substances from plasma into the intestinal lumen, enhancing elimination. Currently, MDAC is indicated for only the following poisons:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Theophylline
  • Phenobarbital
  • Salicylates
  • Dapsone
  • Quinine

questions.text: Vector for malaria in hilly areas and forests______
questions.solution:
Anopheles fluviatilis is the vector for transmitting malaria in hilly areas, forests and forest fringes

Vector

Area

Anopheles stephensi

 

Urban

Anopheles culicifacies

 

Rural

Anopheles fluviatilis

Hilly areas and forests

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil and can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vincent's angina. It is caused by the fusiform bacillus and Borrreli vincentii.

Vincent’s angina:

  • Present with low grade fever and sore throat & membrane over tonsil.
  • Membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcer over tonsil.
  • Throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes namely Borrreli vincentii.

questions.text: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours after sustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury. It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism.

Ophthalmoscopy reveals multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve.

There is no effective treatment.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding Weber’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower face is not seen in Weber's syndrome.There will be contralateral paralysis of the lower face due to UMN lesion of cranial nerve VII.

Weber's syndrome is a form of stroke characterized by the presence of an ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia.

It is caused by midbrain infarction as a result of occlusion of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery or of basilar bifurcation perforating arteries.

Structure damaged

Effect

Cranial nerve III fibers

Ipsilateral ptosis, Ipsilateral divergent squint, loss of accommodation reflex, loss of light reflex

Corticobulbar tract

UMN lesion leading to contralateral paralysis of the lower face

Substantia nigra

Contralateral Parkinsonism

Corticospinal tract

Contralateral hemiplegia

Mnemonic: WEBer= 3 letters= 3rd C.N

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator for long-term nutritional status?
questions.solution:
Height for age is the best indicator for long-term nutritional status (chronic malnutrition).

Weight for age is the most commonly used index, but it does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance. A low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old footballer suffered a twisting injury to his right ankle. On examination, there is a lot of swelling around the medial malleolus and radiograph shows increased medial joint space. The structure injured could be:
questions.solution:
The presence of swelling around the medial malleolus and increased medial joint space in the radiograph indicates injury to the deltoid ligament. 

The deltoid ligament is present on the medial side of the ankle joint and the fibres are attached to the medial malleolus. Hence injury to it can lead to the widening of the medial joint space in the mortise view of the ankle radiograph.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of endometriosis?

choices.text: Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy
Asymptomatic patients are observed over 6–8 months without any need of the infertility workup
Estrogen is the drug of choice for endometriosis
Not all symptomatic women need treatment

questions.solution:
Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy. This is the only true statement.

Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Minimal asymptomatic cases are to be observed over 6–8 months and infertility in such cases should be investigated and treated if necessary.

All symptomatic women do need treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

 Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.

questions.text: A Professor in Psychiatry asks his intern to evaluate a patient using the Folstein test. This test is done out of a score of:
questions.solution:
The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or Folstein test is done out of a score of 30. It consists of a questionnaire for 11 categories, and assesses orientation, attention, calculation, immediate and short-term recall, language, and the ability to follow simple commands. It is used extensively in clinical and research settings to test cognitive functioning.

Score less than 24 is considered as impaired cognition.
